commands.name: find
commands.description: The `find` command is a powerful utility used to search for files and directories within a directory hierarchy. It can search based on various criteria such as name, type, size, modification time, etc.

commands.name: grep
commands.description: The grep command is a powerful text search tool that scans files for lines containing a match to a specified pattern. It is widely used for searching plain-text data sets for lines that match a regular expression.

commands.name: sed
commands.description: The sed command is a stream editor that filters and transforms text, using a simple scripting language. It can perform basic text transformations on an input stream (a file or input from a pipeline).

commands.name: awk
commands.description: The 'awk' command is a powerful text-processing tool that scans each input line, applying a pattern-action program to generate output. It is widely used for data extraction and reporting.

commands.name: ls
commands.description: The 'ls' command is used to list directory contents. It provides a quick overview of files and directories within a specified path, or the current directory if no path is provided.

commands.name: mkdir
commands.description: The mkdir command is used to create new directories. It allows you to organize your files and folders by creating structured hierarchies.

commands.name: rm
commands.description: The 'rm' command is used to remove files or directories. It can also be used to delete multiple files at once.

commands.name: cp
commands.description: The cp command is used to copy files or directories from one location to another. It can also be used to duplicate files within the same directory.

commands.name: mv
commands.description: The 'mv' command is used to move files or directories from one location to another, or to rename them. It can also be used to change the directory of a file without renaming it.

commands.name: ps
commands.description: List running processes

commands.name: top
commands.description: Display running processes dynamically

commands.name: kill
commands.description: Send a signal to a process

commands.name: killall
commands.description: Kill processes by name

commands.name: systemctl
commands.description: Control systemd services

commands.name: service
commands.description: Run System V init scripts

commands.name: docker
commands.description: Docker is a platform that uses OS-level virtualization to package and run applications inside software containers.

commands.name: docker-compose
commands.description: Docker Compose is a tool for defining and running multi-container Docker applications. It uses YAML files to configure services, networks, and volumes, then provides commands to create and start all the containers from your configuration.

commands.name: kubectl
commands.description: kubectl utility

commands.name: git
commands.description: Git is a distributed version control system that tracks changes in source code during software development. It allows multiple developers to work on the same project simultaneously, coordinating their efforts through shared repositories.

commands.name: curl
commands.description: The curl command is a versatile tool for transferring data with URLs. It supports various protocols including HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, and more. It can be used to download files, upload data, or interact with web services.

commands.name: wget
commands.description: Wget is a network utility to download files from the web. It supports HTTP, HTTPS, and FTP protocols, as well as retrieval through HTTP proxies.

commands.name: ping
commands.description: Send ICMP echo requests to test connectivity

commands.name: netstat
commands.description: The netstat command is a network statistics utility that displays network connections, routing tables, interface statistics, masquerade connections, and multicast memberships.

commands.name: ss
commands.description: Display socket statistics

commands.name: lsof
commands.description: List open files

commands.name: df
commands.description: The `df` command is used to report file system disk space usage. It provides a summary of available disk space on each mounted filesystem.

commands.name: du
commands.description: The 'du' command is used to estimate file space usage. It summarizes the disk space used by each argument, recursively for directories.

commands.name: free
commands.description: Display amount of free and used memory

commands.name: uname
commands.description: Print system information

commands.name: whoami
commands.description: Print current user name

commands.name: id
commands.description: The `id` command is used to display or change a user's real and effective user ID, group ID, and supplementary groups. It provides information about the identity of the current process.

commands.name: chmod
commands.description: The chmod command is used to change the file mode bits of a specified file or directory. It allows you to set permissions for the owner, group, and others in terms of read, write, and execute access.

commands.name: chown
commands.description: The chown command is used to change the owner and group of files or directories. It allows system administrators to assign ownership and permissions, ensuring that only authorized users can access and modify critical system files.

commands.name: chgrp
commands.description: The chgrp command is used to change the group ownership of files or directories. It allows you to assign a new group to one or more files, which can affect file permissions and access control.

commands.name: tar
commands.description: The tar command is a utility in Unix-like operating systems that is used to create archive files, which are collections of multiple files and directories. It can also extract files from archives and list the contents of an archive.

commands.name: zip
commands.description: zip utility

commands.name: unzip
commands.description: The unzip command is used to extract files from a ZIP archive. It can decompress and list the contents of a ZIP file without extracting it.

commands.name: gzip
commands.description: Compresses files using the GNU zip format to reduce their size.

commands.name: gunzip
commands.description: The gunzip command is used to decompress files that have been compressed using the gzip utility. It removes the .gz extension from the file and restores the original file.

commands.name: ssh
commands.description: ssh utility

commands.name: scp
commands.description: scp utility

commands.name: rsync
commands.description: rsync is a fast, versatile file-copying tool that can synchronize files and directories between two locations, either locally or over a network. It supports incremental updates, compression, and various options for controlling the transfer process.

commands.name: history
commands.description: Display command history

commands.name: echo
commands.description: Display a line of text

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: do not output the trailing newline

commands.name: printf
commands.description: The printf command is a utility in Unix-like operating systems that interprets and formats data according to a specified format string. It outputs the formatted data to the standard output (usually the terminal).

commands.name: cat
commands.description: Concatenate files and print on the standard output. It is often used to view the contents of a file or combine multiple files into one.

commands.name: less
commands.description: less utility

commands.name: more
commands.description: more utility

commands.name: head
commands.description: The `head` command is used to display the first part of a file, typically the first 10 lines. It is useful for quickly previewing the beginning content of a file.

commands.name: tail
commands.description: The 'tail' command is used to display the last part of a file, typically the last 10 lines. It is useful for monitoring log files or following new entries in real-time.

commands.name: sort
commands.description: Sorts lines of text files or standard input alphabetically or numerically.

commands.name: uniq
commands.description: The uniq command is a utility that removes duplicate lines from a sorted file or input stream, displaying only one copy of each line.

commands.name: wc
commands.description: Counts the number of lines, words, and bytes in files. If no file is specified, it reads from standard input.

commands.name: tr
commands.description: The tr command is used to translate or delete characters from standard input, using the character set specified by SET1 and optionally SET2. It can be used for simple text transformations such as converting uppercase to lowercase or removing specific characters.

commands.name: cut
commands.description: The cut command is used to extract sections from each line of files. It can split lines into fields based on delimiters or character positions.

commands.name: paste
commands.description: The paste command is used to merge lines from multiple files or standard input into a single output line, separated by tabs.

commands.name: join
commands.description: The join command is used to combine two files based on a common field, typically the first field. It outputs lines that have matching fields in both input files.

commands.name: split
commands.description: The split command is used to split a file into smaller files of a specified size or number of lines. This can be useful for distributing large files across multiple storage devices or for processing large files in chunks.

commands.name: xargs
commands.description: xargs is a utility that builds and executes command lines from standard input. It reads items from standard input, forming command lines from them, and then executes those commands.

commands.name: which
commands.description: Locate a command in the PATH

commands.name: whereis
commands.description: Locate binary and manual files

commands.name: man
commands.description: The 'man' command is used to display manual pages, which provide detailed information on various commands, utilities, and system calls available in Unix-like operating systems.

commands.name: info
commands.description: Displays detailed information about files, directories, or system components.

commands.name: date
commands.description: The 'date' command is used to display or set the system date and time. It can also format the output according to a specified pattern.

commands.name: uptime
commands.description: Tell how long the system has been running

commands.name: time
commands.description: The 'time' command is used to measure the execution time of a command or script. It provides detailed timing information including real, user, and system time.

commands.name: sleep
commands.description: The sleep command is used to pause the execution of a script or program for a specified amount of time. This can be useful for creating delays, waiting for processes to complete, or synchronizing actions.

commands.name: watch
commands.description: watch utility

commands.name: nohup
commands.description: The 'nohup' command is used to run a specified command immune to hangups, with output appended to a file, by default 'nohup.out'.

commands.name: pkill
commands.description: pkill utility

commands.name: pgrep
commands.description: pgrep utility

commands.name: pidof
commands.description: pidof utility

commands.name: nice
commands.description: The nice command is used to run a program with an adjusted niceness value, which affects the priority of the process. Higher niceness values mean lower priority.

commands.name: renice
commands.description: renice utility

commands.name: ionice
commands.description: ionice utility

commands.name: timeout
commands.description: The timeout command allows you to specify a maximum time limit for the execution of a command. If the command does not complete within the specified duration, it will be terminated.

commands.name: flock
commands.description: flock utility

commands.name: screen
commands.description: screen utility

commands.name: vim
commands.description: vim utility

commands.name: nano
commands.description: Nano is a small, friendly text editor written by Joe Travers. It is designed to be an easy-to-use alternative to other text editors like vi or emacs.

commands.name: code
commands.description: Generates code snippets or files based on specified options and paths

commands.name: python
commands.description: python utility

commands.name: python3
commands.description: Python3 is an interpreted, high-level, general-purpose programming language. It's widely used for web development, data analysis, artificial intelligence, scientific computing, and more.

commands.name: pip
commands.description: pip utility

commands.name: pip3
commands.description: pip3 utility

commands.name: node
commands.description: Node.js is a JavaScript runtime built on Chrome's V8 JavaScript engine. It allows developers to run JavaScript code outside of a web browser, enabling the development of server-side applications.

commands.name: gcc
commands.description: GCC (GNU Compiler Collection) is a set of compilers and tools that are used to compile C, C++, Objective-C, Fortran, Ada, and Go programming languages into machine code.

commands.name: g++
commands.description: The g++ command is a compiler that translates C++ source code into executable programs. It supports various options to control the compilation process, including optimization levels, debugging information, and target architecture.

commands.name: make
commands.description: The 'make' command is a build automation tool that reads files called Makefiles which specify how to derive the target program. It automatically builds executable programs and libraries from source code by using rules in the Makefile.

commands.name: cmake
commands.description: cmake utility

commands.name: cargo
commands.description: Cargo is a package manager, build system, and more for Rust. It helps manage dependencies, build projects, run tests, and publish packages to crates.io.

commands.name: rustc
commands.description: The rustc command is the Rust compiler, which compiles Rust source code into executable programs or libraries.

commands.name: ruby
commands.description: Ruby is a dynamic, open-source programming language with a focus on simplicity and productivity. It has an elegant syntax that is natural to read and easy to write.

commands.name: gem
commands.description: gem utility

commands.name: perl
commands.description: Perl is a powerful, high-level programming language known for its simplicity and versatility. It is widely used for scripting, web development, system administration, network programming, and more.

commands.name: php
commands.description: The PHP command is a widely-used scripting language interpreter that executes PHP code. It can run scripts from files, read from standard input, or interactively through a shell interface.
